name: src/datetime.js
DateTime
description:
A DateTime is an immutable data structure representing a specific date and time and accompanying methods. It contains class and instance methods for creating, parsing, interrogating, transforming, and formatting them.

A DateTime comprises of:
* A timestamp. Each DateTime instance refers to a specific millisecond of the Unix epoch.
* A time zone. Each instance is considered in the context of a specific zone (by default the local system's zone).
* Configuration properties that effect how output strings are formatted, such as `locale`, `numberingSystem`, and `outputCalendar`.

Here is a brief overview of the most commonly used functionality it provides:

* **Creation**: To create a DateTime from its components, use one of its factory class methods: {@link local}, {@link utc}, and (most flexibly) {@link fromObject}. To create one from a standard string format, use {@link fromISO}, {@link fromHTTP}, and {@link fromRFC2822}. To create one from a custom string format, use {@link fromString}. To create one from a native JS date, use {@link fromJSDate}.
* **Gregorian calendar and time**: To examine the Gregorian properties of a DateTime individually (i.e as opposed to collectively through {@link toObject}), use the {@link year}, {@link month},
{@link day}, {@link hour}, {@link minute}, {@link second}, {@link millisecond} accessors.
* **Week calendar**: For ISO week calendar attributes, see the {@link weekYear}, {@link weekNumber}, and {@link weekday} accessors.
* **Configuration** See the {@link locale} and {@link numberingSystem} accessors.
* **Transformation**: To transform the DateTime into other DateTimes, use {@link set}, {@link reconfigure}, {@link setZone}, {@link setLocale}, {@link plus}, {@link minus}, {@link endOf}, {@link startOf}, {@link toUTC}, and {@link toLocal}.
* **Output**: To convert the DateTime to other representations, use the {@link toJSON}, {@link toISO}, {@link toHTTP}, {@link toObject}, {@link toRFC2822}, {@link toString}, {@link toLocaleString}, {@link toFormat}, {@link valueOf} and {@link toJSDate}.

There's plenty others documented below. In addition, for more information on subtler topics like internationalization, time zones, alternative calendars, validity, and so on, see the external documentation.

name: local
description: Create a local DateTime

params.name: year
params.description: The calendar year. If omitted (as in, call `local()` with no arguments), the current time will be used

params.name: hour
params.description: The hour of the day, in 24-hour time

params.name: minute
params.description: The minute of the hour, i.e. a number between 0 and 59

params.name: second
params.description: The second of the minute, i.e. a number between 0 and 59

params.name: millisecond
params.description: The millisecond of the second, i.e. a number between 0 and 999

name: utc
description: Create a DateTime in UTC

params.name: year
params.description: The calendar year. If omitted (as in, call `utc()` with no arguments), the current time will be used

params.name: hour
params.description: The hour of the day, in 24-hour time

params.name: minute
params.description: The minute of the hour, i.e. a number between 0 and 59

params.name: second
params.description: The second of the minute, i.e. a number between 0 and 59

params.name: millisecond
params.description: The millisecond of the second, i.e. a number between 0 and 999

name: fromJSDate
description: Create an DateTime from a Javascript Date object. Uses the default zone.

params.name: options.zone
params.description: the zone to place the DateTime into

name: fromMillis
description: Create an DateTime from a count of epoch milliseconds. Uses the default zone.

params.name: milliseconds
params.description: a number of milliseconds since 1970 UTC

params.name: options.zone
params.description: the zone to place the DateTime into

params.name: options.locale
params.description: a locale to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: options.outputCalendar
params.description: the output calendar to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: options.numberingSystem
params.description: the numbering system to set on the resulting DateTime instance

name: fromObject
description: Create an DateTime from a Javascript object with keys like 'year' and 'hour' with reasonable defaults.
examples: DateTime.fromObject({ hour: 10, minute: 26, second: 6 }) //~> today at 10:26:06

params.name: obj
params.description: the object to create the DateTime from

params.name: obj.day
params.description: a day of the month, 1-31, depending on the month

params.name: obj.weekNumber
params.description: an ISO week number, between 1 and 52 or 53, depending on the year

params.name: obj.weekday
params.description: an ISO weekday, 1-7, where 1 is Monday and 7 is Sunday

params.name: obj.zone
params.description: interpret the numbers in the context of a particular zone. Can take any value taken as the first argument to setZone()

params.name: obj.locale
params.description: a locale to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: obj.outputCalendar
params.description: the output calendar to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: obj.numberingSystem
params.description: the numbering system to set on the resulting DateTime instance

name: fromISO
description: Create a DateTime from an ISO 8601 string

params.name: opts.zone
params.description: use this zone if no offset is specified in the input string itself. Will also convert the time to this zone

params.name: opts.setZone
params.description: override the zone with a fixed-offset zone specified in the string itself, if it specifies one

params.name: opts.locale
params.description: a locale to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: opts.outputCalendar
params.description: the output calendar to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: opts.numberingSystem
params.description: the numbering system to set on the resulting DateTime instance

name: fromRFC2822
description: Create a DateTime from an RFC 2822 string

params.name: opts.zone
params.description: convert the time to this zone. Since the offset is always specified in the string itself, this has no effect on the interpretation of string, merely the zone the resulting DateTime is expressed in.

params.name: opts.setZone
params.description: override the zone with a fixed-offset zone specified in the string itself, if it specifies one

params.name: opts.locale
params.description: a locale to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: opts.outputCalendar
params.description: the output calendar to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: opts.numberingSystem
params.description: the numbering system to set on the resulting DateTime instance

name: fromHTTP
description: Create a DateTime from an HTTP header date

params.name: options.zone
params.description: convert the time to this zone. Since HTTP dates are always in UTC, this has no effect on the interpretation of string, merely the zone the resulting DateTime is expressed in.

params.name: options.setZone
params.description: override the zone with the fixed-offset zone specified in the string. For HTTP dates, this is always UTC, so this option is equivalent to setting the `zone` option to 'utc', but this option is included for consistency with similar methods.

params.name: options.locale
params.description: a locale to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: options.outputCalendar
params.description: the output calendar to set on the resulting DateTime instance

params.name: options.numberingSystem
params.description: the numbering system to set on the resulting DateTime instance

name: fromString
description:
Create a DateTime from an input string and format string
Defaults to en-US if no locale has been specified, regardless of the system's locale

params.name: fmt
params.description: the format the string is expected to be in (see description)

params.name: options.zone
params.description: use this zone if no offset is specified in the input string itself. Will also convert the DateTime to this zone

params.name: options.setZone
params.description: override the zone with a zone specified in the string itself, if it specifies one

params.name: options.locale
params.description: a locale string to use when parsing. Will also set the DateTime to this locale

params.name: options.numberingSystem
params.description: the numbering system to use when parsing. Will also set the resulting DateTime to this numbering system

params.name: options.outputCalendar
params.description: the output calendar to set on the resulting DateTime instance

name: invalid
description: Create an invalid DateTime.

name: get
description: Get the value of unit.

name: isValid
description:
Returns whether the DateTime is valid. Invalid DateTimes occur when:
* The DateTime was created from invalid calendar information, such as the 13th month or February 30
* The DateTime was created by an operation on another invalid date

name: invalidReason
description: Returns an explanation of why this DateTime became invalid, or null if the DateTime is valid

name: locale
description: Get the locale of a DateTime, such 'en-GB'. The locale is used when formatting the DateTime

name: numberingSystem
description: Get the numbering system of a DateTime, such 'beng'. The numbering system is used when formatting the DateTime

name: outputCalendar
description: Get the output calendar of a DateTime, such 'islamic'. The output calendar is used when formatting the DateTime

name: zoneName
description: Get the name of the time zone.

name: year
description: Get the year

name: month
description: Get the month (1-12).

name: day
description: Get the day of the month (1-30ish).

name: hour
description: Get the hour of the day (0-23).

name: minute
description: Get the minute of the hour (0-59).

name: second
description: Get the second of the minute (0-59).

name: millisecond
description: Get the millisecond of the second (0-999).

name: weekYear
description: Get the week year

name: weekNumber
description: Get the week number of the week year (1-52ish).

name: weekday
description:
Get the day of the week.
1 is Monday and 7 is Sunday

name: ordinal
description: Get the ordinal (i.e. the day of the year)

name: monthShort
description:
Get the human readable short month name, such as 'Oct'.
Defaults to the system's locale if no locale has been specified

name: monthLong
description:
Get the human readable long month name, such as 'October'.
Defaults to the system's locale if no locale has been specified

name: weekdayShort
description:
Get the human readable short weekday, such as 'Mon'.
Defaults to the system's locale if no locale has been specified

name: weekdayLong
description:
Get the human readable long weekday, such as 'Monday'.
Defaults to the system's locale if no locale has been specified

name: offset
description: Get the UTC offset of this DateTime in minutes

name: offsetNameShort
description:
Get the short human name for the zone's current offset, for example "EST" or "EDT".
Defaults to the system's locale if no locale has been specified

name: offsetNameLong
description:
Get the long human name for the zone's current offset, for example "Eastern Standard Time" or "Eastern Daylight Time".
Defaults to the system's locale if no locale has been specified

name: isOffsetFixed
description: Get whether this zone's offset ever changes, as in a DST.

name: isInDST
description: Get whether the DateTime is in a DST.

name: isInLeapYear
description: Returns true if this DateTime is in a leap year, false otherwise

name: daysInMonth
description: Returns the number of days in this DateTime's month

name: daysInYear
description: Returns the number of days in this DateTime's year

name: resolvedLocaleOpts
description:
Returns the resolved Intl options for this DateTime.
This is useful in understanding the behavior of formatting methods

name: toUTC
description:
"Set" the DateTime's zone to UTC. Returns a newly-constructed DateTime.

Equivalent to {@link setZone}('utc')

params.name: offset
params.description: optionally, an offset from UTC in minutes

name: toLocal
description:
"Set" the DateTime's zone to the host's local zone. Returns a newly-constructed DateTime.

Equivalent to `setZone('local')`

name: setZone
description:
"Set" the DateTime's zone to specified zone. Returns a newly-constructed DateTime.

By default, the setter keeps the underlying time the same (as in, the same UTC timestamp), but the new instance will report different local times and consider DSTs when making computations, as with {@link plus}. You may wish to use {@link toLocal} and {@link toUTC} which provide simple convenience wrappers for commonly used zones.

params.name: zone
params.description: a zone identifier. As a string, that can be any IANA zone supported by the host environment, or a fixed-offset name of the form 'utc+3', or the strings 'local' or 'utc'. You may also supply an instance of a {@link Zone} class.

params.name: opts.keepCalendarTime
params.description: If true, adjust the underlying time so that the local time stays the same, but in the target zone. You should rarely need this.

name: reconfigure
description: "Set" the locale, numberingSystem, or outputCalendar. Returns a newly-constructed DateTime.

name: setLocale
description:
"Set" the locale. Returns a newly-constructed DateTime.
Just a convenient alias for reconfigure({ locale })

name: set
description: "Set" the values of specified units. Returns a newly-constructed DateTime.

params.name: values
params.description: a mapping of units to numbers

name: plus
description:
Add a period of time to this DateTime and return the resulting DateTime

Adding hours, minutes, seconds, or milliseconds increases the timestamp by the right number of milliseconds. Adding days, months, or years shifts the calendar, accounting for DSTs and leap years along the way. Thus, `dt.plus({ hours: 24 })` may result in a different time than `dt.plus({ days: 1 })` if there's a DST shift in between.
examples: DateTime.local().plus({ hours: 3, minutes: 13 }) //~> in 1 hr, 13 min

params.name: duration
params.description: The amount to add. Either a Luxon Duration, a number of milliseconds, the object argument to Duration.fromObject()

name: minus
description:
Subtract a period of time to this DateTime and return the resulting DateTime
See {@link plus}

params.name: duration
params.description: The amount to subtract. Either a Luxon Duration, a number of milliseconds, the object argument to Duration.fromObject()

name: startOf
description: "Set" this DateTime to the beginning of a unit of time.

params.name: unit
params.description: The unit to go to the beginning of. Can be 'year', 'month', 'day', 'hour', 'minute', 'second', or 'millisecond'.

name: endOf
description: "Set" this DateTime to the end (i.e. the last millisecond) of a unit of time

params.name: unit
params.description: The unit to go to the end of. Can be 'year', 'month', 'day', 'hour', 'minute', 'second', or 'millisecond'.

name: toFormat
description:
Returns a string representation of this DateTime formatted according to the specified format string.
**You may not want this.** See {@link toLocaleString} for a more flexible formatting tool. See the documentation for the specific format tokens supported.
Defaults to en-US if no locale has been specified, regardless of the system's locale
examples: DateTime.local().toFormat("HH 'hours and' mm 'minutes'") //=> '20 hours and 55 minutes'

name: toLocaleString
description:
Returns a localized string representing this date. Accepts the same options as the Intl.DateTimeFormat constructor and any presets defined by Luxon, such as `DateTime.DATE_FULL` or `DateTime.TIME_SIMPLE`.
The exact behavior of this method is browser-specific, but in general it will return an appropriate representation.
of the DateTime in the assigned locale.
Defaults to the system's locale if no locale has been specified
examples: DateTime.local().toLocaleString({weekday: 'long', month: 'long', day: '2-digit', hour: '2-digit', minute: '2-digit'}); //=> 'Thu, Apr 20, 11:27'

name: toLocaleParts
description:
Returns an array of format "parts", i.e. individual tokens along with metadata. This is allows callers to post-process individual sections of the formatted output.
Defaults to the system's locale if no locale has been specified

name: toISO
description: Returns an ISO 8601-compliant string representation of this DateTime

params.name: opts.suppressMilliseconds
params.description: exclude milliseconds from the format if they're 0

params.name: opts.supressSeconds
params.description: exclude seconds from the format if they're 0

name: toISODate
description: Returns an ISO 8601-compliant string representation of this DateTime's date component

name: toISOWeekDate
description: Returns an ISO 8601-compliant string representation of this DateTime's week date

name: toISOTime
description: Returns an ISO 8601-compliant string representation of this DateTime's time component

params.name: opts.suppressMilliseconds
params.description: exclude milliseconds from the format if they're 0

params.name: opts.supressSeconds
params.description: exclude seconds from the format if they're 0

name: toRFC2822
description: Returns an RFC 2822-compatible string representation of this DateTime, always in UTC

name: toHTTP
description:
Returns a string representation of this DateTime appropriate for use in HTTP headers.
Specifically, the string conforms to RFC 1123.

name: toString
description: Returns a string representation of this DateTime appropriate for debugging

name: valueOf
description: Returns the epoch milliseconds of this DateTime

name: toJSON
description: Returns an ISO 8601 representation of this DateTime appropriate for use in JSON.

name: toObject
description: Returns a Javascript object with this DateTime's year, month, day, and so on.
examples: DateTime.local().toObject() //=> { year: 2017, month: 4, day: 22, hour: 20, minute: 49, second: 42, millisecond: 268 }

params.name: opts.includeConfig
params.description: include configuration attributes in the output

name: toJSDate
description: Returns a Javascript Date equivalent to this DateTime.

name: diff
description: Return the difference between two DateTimes as a Duration.

params.name: otherDateTime
params.description: the DateTime to compare this one to

params.name: unit
params.description: the unit or array of units (such as 'hours' or 'days') to include in the duration.

params.name: opts
params.description: options that affect the creation of the Duration

name: diffNow
description:
Return the difference between this DateTime and right now.
See {@link diff}

params.name: unit
params.description: the unit or units units (such as 'hours' or 'days') to include in the duration

params.name: opts
params.description: options that affect the creation of the Duration

name: until
description: Return an Interval spanning between this DateTime and another DateTime

params.name: otherDateTime
params.description: the other end point of the Interval

name: hasSame
description: Return whether this DateTime is in the same unit of time as another DateTime
examples: DateTime.local().hasSame(otherDT, 'day'); //~> true if both the same calendar day

params.name: unit
params.description: the unit of time to check sameness on

name: equals
description:
Equality check
Two DateTimes are equal iff they represent the same millisecond

name: min
description: Return the min of several date times

params.name: dateTimes
params.description: the DateTimes from which to choose the minimum

name: max
description: Return the max of several date times

params.name: dateTimes
params.description: the DateTimes from which to choose the maximum

name: fromStringExplain
description: Explain how a string would be parsed by fromString()

params.name: fmt
params.description: the format the string is expected to be in (see description)

name: DATE_SHORT
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 10/14/1983

name: DATE_MED
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'Oct 14, 1983'

name: DATE_FULL
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'October 14, 1983'

name: DATE_HUGE
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'Tuesday, October 14, 1983'

name: TIME_SIMPLE
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '09:30 AM'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: TIME_WITH_SECONDS
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '09:30:23 AM'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: TIME_WITH_SHORT_OFFSET
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '09:30:23 AM EDT'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: TIME_WITH_LONG_OFFSET
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '09:30:23 AM Eastern Daylight Time'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: TIME_24_SIMPLE
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '09:30', always 24-hour.

name: TIME_24_WITH_SECONDS
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '09:30:23', always 24-hour.

name: TIME_24_WITH_SHORT_OFFSET
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '09:30:23 EDT', always 24-hour.

name: TIME_24_WITH_LONG_OFFSET
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '09:30:23 Eastern Daylight Time', always 24-hour.

name: DATETIME_SHORT
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '10/14/1983, 9:30 AM'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: DATETIME_SHORT_WITH_SECONDS
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like '10/14/1983, 9:30:33 AM'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: DATETIME_MED
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'Oct 14, 1983, 9:30 AM'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: DATETIME_MED_WITH_SECONDS
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'Oct 14, 1983, 9:30:33 AM'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: DATETIME_FULL
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'October 14, 1983, 9:30 AM EDT'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: DATETIME_FULL_WITH_SECONDS
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'October 14, 1983, 9:303 AM EDT'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: DATETIME_HUGE
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'Friday, October 14, 1983, 9:30 AM Eastern Daylight Time'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: DATETIME_HUGE_WITH_SECONDS
description: {@link toLocaleString} format like 'Friday, October 14, 1983, 9:30:33 AM Eastern Daylight Time'. Only 12-hour if the locale is.

name: src/duration.js
Duration
description:
A Duration object represents a period of time, like "2 months" or "1 day, 1 hour". Conceptually, it's just a map of units to their quantities, accompanied by some additional configuration and methods for creating, parsing, interrogating, transforming, and formatting them. They can be used on their own or in conjunction with other Luxon types; for example, you can use {@link DateTime.plus} to add a Duration object to a DateTime, producing another DateTime.

Here is a brief overview of commonly used methods and getters in Duration:

* **Creation** To create a Duration, use {@link fromMillis}, {@link fromObject}, or {@link fromISO}.
* **Unit values** See the {@link years}, {@link months}, {@link weeks}, {@link days}, {@link hours}, {@link minutes}, {@link seconds}, {@link milliseconds} accessors.
* **Configuration** See  {@link locale} and {@link numberingSystem} accessors.
* **Transformation** To create new Durations out of old ones use {@link plus}, {@link minus}, {@link normalize}, {@link set}, {@link reconfigure}, {@link shiftTo}, and {@link negate}.
* **Output** To convert the Duration into other representations, see {@link as}, {@link toISO}, {@link toFormat}, and {@link toJSON}

There's are more methods documented below. In addition, for more information on subtler topics like internationalization and validity, see the external documentation.

name: fromMillis
description: Create Duration from a number of milliseconds.

name: fromObject
description: Create an DateTime from a Javascript object with keys like 'years' and 'hours'.

params.name: obj
params.description: the object to create the DateTime from

name: fromISO
description: Create a DateTime from an ISO 8601 duration string.
examples: Duration.fromISO('P3Y6M4DT12H30M5S').toObject() //=> { years: 3, months: 6, day: 4, hours: 12, minutes: 30, seconds: 5 }

name: invalid
description: Create an invalid Duration.

name: locale
description: Get  the locale of a Duration, such 'en-GB'

name: numberingSystem
description: Get the numbering system of a Duration, such 'beng'. The numbering system is used when formatting the Duration

name: toFormat
description: Returns a string representation of this Duration formatted according to the specified format string.

name: toObject
description: Returns a Javascript object with this Duration's values.
examples: Duration.fromObject({ years: 1, days: 6, seconds: 2 }).toObject() //=> { years: 1, days: 6, seconds: 2 }

params.name: opts.includeConfig
params.description: include configuration attributes in the output

name: toISO
description: Returns an ISO 8601-compliant string representation of this Duration.

name: toJSON
description: Returns an ISO 8601 representation of this Duration appropriate for use in JSON.

name: toString
description: Returns an ISO 8601 representation of this Duration appropriate for use in debugging.

name: plus
description: Make this Duration longer by the specified amount. Return a newly-constructed Duration.

params.name: duration
params.description: The amount to add. Either a Luxon Duration, a number of milliseconds, the object argument to Duration.fromObject()

name: minus
description: Make this Duration shorter by the specified amount. Return a newly-constructed Duration.

params.name: duration
params.description: The amount to subtract. Either a Luxon Duration, a number of milliseconds, the object argument to Duration.fromObject()

name: get
description: Get the value of unit.

name: set
description: "Set" the values of specified units. Return a newly-constructed Duration.

params.name: values
params.description: a mapping of units to numbers

name: reconfigure
description: "Set" the locale and/or numberingSystem.  Returns a newly-constructed Duration.

name: as
description: Return the length of the duration in the specified unit.

name: normalize
description: Reduce this Duration to its canonical representation in its current units.

name: shiftTo
description: Convert this Duration into its representation in a different set of units.

name: negate
description: Return the negative of this Duration.

name: years
description: Get the years.

name: months
description: Get the months.

name: weeks
description: Get the weeks

name: days
description: Get the days.

name: hours
description: Get the hours.

name: minutes
description: Get the minutes.

name: seconds
description: Get the seconds.

name: milliseconds
description: Get the milliseconds.

name: isValid
description:
Returns whether the Duration is invalid. Invalid durations are returned by diff operations
on invalid DateTimes or Intervals.

name: invalidReason
description: Returns an explanation of why this Duration became invalid, or null if the Duration is valid

name: equals
description:
Equality check
Two Durations are equal iff they have the same units and the same values for each unit.

name: src/errors.js
src/impl/conversions.js
src/impl/english.js
src/impl/formats.js
src/impl/formatter.js
src/impl/locale.js
src/impl/regexParser.js
src/impl/tokenParser.js
src/impl/util.js
src/info.js
Info
description: The Info class contains static methods for retrieving general time and date related data. For example, it has methods for finding out if a time zone has a DST, for listing the months in any supported locale, and for discovering which of Luxon features are available in the current environment.

name: hasDST
description: Return whether the specified zone contains a DST.

params.name: zone
params.description: Zone to check. Defaults to the environment's local zone.

name: months
description: Return an array of standalone month names.

params.name: length
params.description: the length of the month representation, such as "numeric", "2-digit", "narrow", "short", "long"

name: monthsFormat
description:
Return an array of format month names.
Format months differ from standalone months in that they're meant to appear next to the day of the month. In some languages, that
changes the string.
See {@link months}

params.name: length
params.description: the length of the month representation, such as "numeric", "2-digit", "narrow", "short", "long"

name: weekdays
description: Return an array of standalone week names.

params.name: length
params.description: the length of the month representation, such as "narrow", "short", "long".

name: weekdaysFormat
description:
Return an array of format week names.
Format weekdays differ from standalone weekdays in that they're meant to appear next to more date information. In some languages, that
changes the string.
See {@link weekdays}

params.name: length
params.description: the length of the month representation, such as "narrow", "short", "long".

name: meridiems
description: Return an array of meridiems.

name: eras
description: Return an array of eras, such as ['BC', 'AD']. The locale can be specified, but the calendar system is always Gregorian.

params.name: length
params.description: the length of the era representation, such as "short" or "long".

name: features
description:
Return the set of available features in this environment.
Some features of Luxon are not available in all environments. For example, on older browsers, timezone support is not available. Use this function to figure out if that's the case.
Keys:
* `timezones`: whether this environment supports IANA timezones
* `intlTokens`: whether this environment supports internationalized token-based formatting/parsing
* `intl`: whether this environment supports general internationalization
examples: Info.feature() //=> { intl: true, intlTokens: false, timezones: true }

name: src/interval.js
Interval
description:
An Interval object represents a half-open interval of time, where each endpoint is a {@link DateTime}. Conceptually, it's a container for those two endpoints, accompanied by methods for creating, parsing, interrogating, comparing, transforming, and formatting them.

Here is a brief overview of the most commonly used methods and getters in Interval:

* **Creation** To create an Interval, use {@link fromDateTimes}, {@link after}, {@link before}, or {@link fromISO}.
* **Accessors** Use {@link start} and {@link end} to get the start and end.
* **Interogation** To analyze the Interval, use {@link count}, {@link length}, {@link hasSame}, {@link contains}, {@link isAfter}, or {@link isBefore}.
* **Transformation** To create other Intervals out of this one, use {@link set}, {@link splitAt}, {@link splitBy}, {@link divideEqually}, {@link merge}, {@link xor}, {@link union}, {@link intersection}, or {@link difference}.
* **Comparison** To compare this Interval to another one, use {@link equals}, {@link overlaps}, {@link abutsStart}, {@link abutsEnd}, {@link engulfs}
* **Output*** To convert the Interval into other representations, see {@link toString}, {@link toISO}, {@link toFormat}, and {@link toDuration}.

name: invalid
description: Create an invalid Interval.

name: fromDateTimes
description: Create an Interval from a start DateTime and an end DateTime. Inclusive of the start but not the end.

name: after
description: Create an Interval from a start DateTime and a Duration to extend to.

name: before
description: Create an Interval from an end DateTime and a Duration to extend backwards to.

name: fromISO
description: Create an Interval from an ISO 8601 string

name: start
description: Returns the start of the Interval

name: end
description: Returns the end of the Interval

name: isValid
description: Returns whether this Interval's end is at least its start, i.e. that the Interval isn't 'backwards'.

name: invalidReason
description: Returns an explanation of why this Interval became invalid, or null if the Interval is valid

name: length
description: Returns the length of the Interval in the specified unit.

params.name: unit
params.description: the unit (such as 'hours' or 'days') to return the length in.

name: count
description:
Returns the count of minutes, hours, days, months, or years included in the Interval, even in part.
Unlike {@link length} this counts sections of the calendar, not periods of time, e.g. specifying 'day'
asks 'what dates are included in this interval?', not 'how many days long is this interval?'

params.name: unit
params.description: the unit of time to count.

name: hasSame
description: Returns whether this Interval's start and end are both in the same unit of time

params.name: unit
params.description: the unit of time to check sameness on

name: isEmpty
description: Return whether this Interval has the same start and end DateTimes.

name: isAfter
description: Return this Interval's start is after the specified DateTime.

name: isBefore
description: Return this Interval's end is before the specified DateTime.

name: contains
description: Return this Interval contains the specified DateTime.

name: set
description: "Sets" the start and/or end dates. Returns a newly-constructed Interval.

name: splitAt
description: Split this Interval at each of the specified DateTimes

params.name: dateTimes
params.description: the unit of time to count.

name: splitBy
description:
Split this Interval into smaller Intervals, each of the specified length.
Left over time is grouped into a smaller interval

params.name: duration
params.description: The length of each resulting interval.

name: divideEqually
description: Split this Interval into the specified number of smaller intervals.

params.name: numberOfParts
params.description: The number of Intervals to divide the Interval into.

name: overlaps
description: Return whether this Interval overlaps with the specified Interval

name: abutsStart
description: Return whether this Interval's end is adjacent to the specified Interval's start.

name: abutsEnd
description: Return whether this Interval's start is adjacent to the specified Interval's end.

name: engulfs
description: Return whether this Interval engulfs the start and end of the specified Interval.

name: equals
description: Return whether this Interval has the same start and end as the specified Interval.

name: intersection
description:
Return an Interval representing the intersection of this Interval and the specified Interval.
Specifically, the resulting Interval has the maximum start time and the minimum end time of the two Intervals.

name: union
description:
Return an Interval representing the union of this Interval and the specified Interval.
Specifically, the resulting Interval has the minimum start time and the maximum end time of the two Intervals.

name: merge
description:
Merge an array of Intervals into a equivalent minimal set of Intervals.
Combines overlapping and adjacent Intervals.

name: xor
description: Return an array of Intervals representing the spans of time that only appear in one of the specified Intervals.

name: difference
description: Return an Interval representing the span of time in this Interval that doesn't overlap with any of the specified Intervals.

name: toString
description: Returns a string representation of this Interval appropriate for debugging.

name: toISO
description: Returns an ISO 8601-compliant string representation of this Interval.

name: toFormat
description: Returns a string representation of this Interval formatted according to the specified format string.

params.name: dateFormat
params.description: the format string. This string formats the start and end time. See {@link DateTime.toFormat} for details.

params.name: opts.separator
params.description: a separator to place between the start and end representations

name: toDuration
description: Return a Duration representing the time spanned by this interval.

params.name: unit
params.description: the unit or units (such as 'hours' or 'days') to include in the duration.

params.name: opts
params.description: options that affect the creation of the Duration

name: src/luxon.js
src/luxonFilled.js
src/settings.js
Settings
description: Settings contains static getters and setters that control Luxon's overall behavior. Luxon is a simple library with few options, but the ones it does have live here.

name: now
description: Get the callback for returning the current timestamp.

name: now
description: Set the callback for returning the current timestamp.

name: defaultZoneName
description: Get the default time zone to create DateTimes in.

name: defaultZoneName
description: Set the default time zone to create DateTimes in. Does not affect existing instances.

name: defaultZone
description: Get the default time zone object to create DateTimes in. Does not affect existing instances.

name: defaultLocale
description: Get the default locale to create DateTimes with. Does not affect existing instances.

name: defaultLocale
description: Set the default locale to create DateTimes with. Does not affect existing instances.

name: defaultNumberingSystem
description: Get the default numbering system to create DateTimes with. Does not affect existing instances.

name: defaultNumberingSystem
description: Set the default numbering system to create DateTimes with. Does not affect existing instances.

name: defaultOutputCalendar
description: Get the default output calendar to create DateTimes with. Does not affect existing instances.

name: defaultOutputCalendar
description: Set the default output calendar to create DateTimes with. Does not affect existing instances.

name: throwOnInvalid
description: Get whether Luxon will throw when it encounters invalid DateTimes, Durations, or Intervals

name: throwOnInvalid
description: Set whether Luxon will throw when it encounters invalid DateTimes, Durations, or Intervals

name: resetCaches
description: Reset Luxon's global caches. Should only be necessary in testing scenarios.

name: src/zone.js
type
description: The type of zone

name: name
description: The name of this zone.

name: universal
description: Returns whether the offset is known to be fixed for the whole year.

name: offsetName
description: Returns the offset's common name (such as EST) at the specified timestamp

params.name: ts
params.description: Epoch milliseconds for which to get the name

params.name: opts.format
params.description: What style of offset to return. Accepts 'long' or 'short'.

params.name: opts.localeCode
params.description: What locale to return the offset name in. Defaults to us-en

name: offset
description: Return the offset in minutes for this zone at the specified timestamp.

params.name: ts
params.description: Epoch milliseconds for which to compute the offset

name: equals
description: Return whether this Zone is equal to another zoner

name: isValid
description: Return whether this Zone is valid.

name: src/zones/IANAZone.js
src/zones/fixedOffsetZone.js
src/zones/localZone.js
